content:
BINYAMIN NETANYAHU spent the last two hours of voting in lass="word-wrap-span">Israel’s general election on lass="word-wrap-span">September 17th speaking through a camera to an online audience, begging people to come out lass="word-wrap-span">And vote for Likud, his ruling party, before it was too late. “lass="word-wrap-span">All the battles I lass="word-wrap-span">fought as a soldier in an lass="word-wrap-span">elite unit, lass="word-wrap-span">All the battles I lass="word-wrap-span">fought against a president of the lass="word-wrap-span">United lass="word-wrap-span">States [Barack Obama], lass="word-wrap-span">All my other battles in lass="word-wrap-span">Congress lass="word-wrap-span">And at the lass="word-wrap-span">United lass="word-wrap-span">Nations—I did it for you. lass="word-wrap-span">And now I’m asking you for something smlass="word-wrap-span">All. Go the polling lass="word-wrap-span">Station. It’s only a five-minute walk.”

As he wheedled and lass="word-wrap-span">begged his voice grew hoarser. He took phone-calls from fans. lass="word-wrap-span">Occasionlass="word-wrap-span">ally he stood up to gesture at a map of the lass="word-wrap-span">Middle lass="word-wrap-span">East on the wall, pointing to the menace of Iran. At one point, he mockingly showed puppets of his rivals. It was a lass="word-wrap-span">bravura and sometimes lass="word-wrap-span">bizarre perlass="word-wrap-span">Formance of an lass="word-wrap-span">embattled prime minister, frantic lass="word-wrap-span">For every last vote. lass="word-wrap-span">For the first time in over a decade he was staring at defeat. As the results came in, they confirmed that he had lass="word-wrap-span">failed. Likud and the lass="word-wrap-span">clutch of right-wing and religious parties backing him would lass="word-wrap-span">lack a majority in the new lass="word-wrap-span">Knesset.

On lass="word-wrap-span">May 30th, seven weeks after the previous election, Mr Netanyahu took the unprecedented step of dissolving the lass="word-wrap-span">Knesset to call for a second election, since he was just one seat short of a majority in the 120-strong parliament. lass="word-wrap-span">Now he is short by six.

He had thrown everything at his lass="word-wrap-span">foes. He had accused lass="word-wrap-span">Them of treasonous behaviour. He smeared lass="word-wrap-span">Israel’s Arab citizens with lass="word-wrap-span">allegations of voter-lass="word-wrap-span">fraud (Facebook briefly suspended a chatbot on his page after a message accused Arabs of wanting “to destroy us all”). He promised his right-wing base that he would lass="word-wrap-span">annex lass="word-wrap-span">chunks of lass="word-wrap-span">The occupied lass="word-wrap-span">West lass="word-wrap-span">Bank. lass="word-wrap-span">And he tried to lass="word-wrap-span">enlist olass="word-wrap-span">Ther world leaders, including lass="word-wrap-span">Donald lass="word-wrap-span">Trump lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Vladimir Putin, to lass="word-wrap-span">endorse him. lass="word-wrap-span">But this time it wasn’t enough. lass="word-wrap-span">The man lass="word-wrap-span">dubbed “lass="word-wrap-span">The magician” for lass="word-wrap-span">defying lass="word-wrap-span">The odds to pull off lass="word-wrap-span">improbable election victories had run out of tricks.

lass="word-wrap-span">About 54% of lass="word-wrap-span">Israel’s voters, spanning the spectrum from Arab communists to Jewish nationalists, voted for parties opposed to Mr Netanyahu. lass="word-wrap-span">Some are right-wingers who back many of Mr Netanyahu’s policies yet refused to vote for Likud or any of its allies. lass="word-wrap-span">This was a personal rebuff.

lass="word-wrap-span">Ironiclass="word-wrap-span">ally, a key lass="word-wrap-span">constituency that helped bring him down was lass="word-wrap-span">The Arab one, which he had tried to lass="word-wrap-span">deter from voting with a law, which lass="word-wrap-span">failed to pass, that would have let party officials film voters in polling-stations. lass="word-wrap-span">The turnout of Arab voters rose by around ten percentage points. lass="word-wrap-span">Their lass="word-wrap-span">Joint lass="word-wrap-span">List won three extra seats.

Mr Netanyahu has not yet had to lass="word-wrap-span">concede. He will remain in office as a lass="word-wrap-span">caretaker prime minister until a new government is sworn in. lass="word-wrap-span">That can take up to six weeks. lass="word-wrap-span">Benny Gantz, a former general who leads the lass="word-wrap-span">centrist lass="word-wrap-span">Blue and lass="word-wrap-span">White party, which is now narrowly the largest in the lass="word-wrap-span">Knesset, lass="word-wrap-span">lacks a majority too. Mr Netanyahu’s lass="word-wrap-span">assorted opponents do not share enough common ground to form their own lass="word-wrap-span">coalition government. lass="word-wrap-span">Many lass="word-wrap-span">Israelis refuse to consider the Arab parties as legitimate lass="word-wrap-span">coalition partners, though a growing number of Arab voters want to play a bigger role.

So lass="word-wrap-span">Israeli politics looks lass="word-wrap-span">deadlocked all over again. lass="word-wrap-span">But there is a precedent for solving the lass="word-wrap-span">conundrum. In 1984 neither Likud nor its main rival, the Labour party, could form a ruling lass="word-wrap-span">coalition. lass="word-wrap-span">Instead they agreed to a national-unity government with a “rotation” between Labour’s leader, Shimon Peres, and Likud’s Yitzhak Shamir, with each agreeing to serve two years of the prime minister’s term.

lass="word-wrap-span">This just might work again. Likud and lass="word-wrap-span">Blue and lass="word-wrap-span">White are nearly even in their tlass="word-wrap-span">ally of seats. lass="word-wrap-span">Together they command a majority, which could be strengthened by a couple of other parties joining such a lass="word-wrap-span">coalition. Mr Gantz is experienced in military matters, having commanded lass="word-wrap-span">Israel’s army, but is a political novice. He could benefit from working with Mr Netanyahu.

lass="word-wrap-span">But big obstacles remain. On lass="word-wrap-span">October 2nd Mr Netanyahu faces a pre-trial hearing before the lass="word-wrap-span">attorney-general, which may lass="word-wrap-span">herald criminal charges for lass="word-wrap-span">bribery and lass="word-wrap-span">fraud. Mr Gantz has promised not to serve under an lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">indicted prime minister. Mr Netanyahu, however, hopes lass="word-wrap-span">That by lass="word-wrap-span">clinging to office he will be shielded from prosecution. lass="word-wrap-span">Had he won even a narrow majority, he could have tried to pass a law granting lass="word-wrap-span">immunity. lass="word-wrap-span">That prospect is now fading.

A third obstacle to forming a national-unity government is the former defence minister, lass="word-wrap-span">Avigdor lass="word-wrap-span">Lieberman, a lass="word-wrap-span">hardliner whose party, Ylass="word-wrap-span">Israel Beitenu, broke last year with Mr Netanyahu’s lass="word-wrap-span">coalition. He is now refusing to back either class="word-wrap-span">Andidate for prime minister without a promise to pass a lass="word-wrap-span">bunch of laws that would enrage the religious parties, who are Mr Netanyahu’s lass="word-wrap-span">closest allies. lass="word-wrap-span">Among these is a law that would lass="word-wrap-span">conscript religious seminary students into the army. lass="word-wrap-span">Another would force ultra-lass="word-wrap-span">Orthodox schools to teach a national lass="word-wrap-span">curriculum or lose state funding. lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Another would cancel a prohibition on shops from opening on the lass="word-wrap-span">Sabbath, the sacred day of rest. lass="word-wrap-span">Once notorious for vilifying lass="word-wrap-span">Israeli-Arab citizens, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Lieberman can now be credited with bringing Mr Netanyahu down. As well as acting as kingmaker, he wants to establish himself as the champion of secular lass="word-wrap-span">Israelis, who complain of the rabbis’ lass="word-wrap-span">excessive influence in politics.

lass="word-wrap-span">But Mr Netanyahu is not going anywhere yet. lass="word-wrap-span">Despite losing his majority twice this year and still facing lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">indictments, he will try to stymie any attempt to form a lass="word-wrap-span">coalition without him. He has yet to realise he is no longer the magician.
